title: feat: under support for regex
body:
The undo part accepts different kinds of input:
- A single char — effectively the next one after running `¤`
- A single string — replaces all entries with the same string
- Array of strings with length equal to the amount of matches — replaces each entry with the corresponding string
- 2d array of strings — effectively the previous one after running `≡⊢`, needed for `⍜regex∘` to work

In all four cases, the replacement strings may optionally be boxed.

title: fix(nix): fix wasm-bindgen version
body: A previous commit (#791) downgraded `wasm-bindgen`, which caused the site derivation to break.

body:
Bumps [webpki-roots](https://github.com/rustls/webpki-roots) from 0.26.8 to 1.0.2.
Release notes

Sourced from webpki-roots's releases.

1.0.2

  • Add "TrustAsia TLS ECC Root CA" and "TrustAsia TLS RSA Root CA" https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=1972384
  • Add "SwissSign RSA TLS Root CA 2022 - 1" https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=1845047

What's Changed

  • Update dependencies by @​djc in rustls/webpki-roots#102
  • 1.0.2: track July 2025 CCADB changes by @​ctz in rustls/webpki-roots#103

Full Changelog: https://github.com/rustls/webpki-roots/compare/v/1.0.1...v/1.0.2

1.0.1

Remove Chunghwa Telecom "ePKI Root Certification Authority". See the upstream issue for details.

What's Changed

  • 1.0.1: June 2025 updates by @​ctz in rustls/webpki-roots#101

Full Changelog: https://github.com/rustls/webpki-roots/compare/v/1.0.0...v/1.0.1

1.0.0

After 51 releases over about nine years, this is the first stable release of the webpki-roots and webpki-root-certs crates.

The 1.0.0 release is functionally equal to the 0.26.10 release. We will make a 0.26.11 release that uses 1.0.0 using the semver trick.

What's Changed

  • Refine CI workflow triggers by @​djc in rustls/webpki-roots#97
  • Prepare 1.0.0 by @​ctz in rustls/webpki-roots#98

Full Changelog: https://github.com/rustls/webpki-roots/compare/v/0.26.10...v/1.0.0

0.26.11

This is the final 0.26.x release of the webpki-roots and webpki-root-certs crates. It depends upon and re-exports 1.0.0 using the "semver trick", meaning people depending on 0.26.x will nevertheless get future 1.x.y releases.

What's Changed

  • Refine CI workflow triggers by @​djc in rustls/webpki-roots#97
  • 0.26.11: Prepare webpki-{roots,root-certs} semver trick by @​ctz in rustls/webpki-roots#99

Full Changelog: https://github.com/rustls/webpki-roots/compare/v/0.26.10...v/0.26.11

0.26.10

Incorporates CCADB April updates.

Roots removed due to https://wiki.mozilla.org/CA/Root_CA_Lifecycles / https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=1957685:

  • "AAA Certificate Services"
  • "Baltimore CyberTrust Root"

... (truncated)

  • 944d375 Upgrade to webpki 0.103
  • dd51e4d Prepare 1.0.1
  • 6a4bf92 Take upstream changes
  • Additional commits viewable in compare view

title: fix indexof with sorted flag not returning first index
fix(test): enable ffi tests on macos
Changelog fixes
body: I went through PRs to 0.17 and found a couple things that hadn't been changelogged. I also fixed the grammar/formatting of one of the bullets.

title: Add `un` and `under` inverses for `&cd`
body:
- `°&cd` will output the current directory.
- `⍜&cd` will switch back to the original directory after calling `⍜`'s second function.

title: Name values being inserted into format strings directly in the string where possible
body: Clippy was complaining about these, so I went ahead and fixed them.

title: Add alternate Index Of glyph and fix subscript 1, 2 and 3
Add `each` alias for `rows,0`
body: I'm not familiar with the `Sequence` trait but it looks like it supports `i16` but not `i32`.

title: fix: rename trunk.toml to Trunk.toml
body: `trunk` expects its configuration to be in a file named `Trunk.toml`. Some operating systems use case-insensitive filesystems by default, which causes `trunk.toml` to _accidentally_ work there. On other systems, or with non-default settings, this causes [issues](https://github.com/uiua-lang/uiua/pull/792#issuecomment-3120154947).

title: nix: remove apple frameworks and extra libffi usage
body:
Removed `libffi` being explicitly listed in the `mkShell` because `inputsFrom = builtins.attrValues self'.packages;` already pulls in every dependency of the main build (which already uses `libffi`).

Removed the usage of `darwin.apple_sdk.frameworks` and `libiconv`. They are part of the `stdenv` on darwin by default, no need to list them explicitly anymore.

I did not bump the nixpkgs used revision.

title: fix textarea line-height and overlay .code-line height misalignment
Rename `modulus` to `modulo`
body: Disussed and approved in Discord

title: fix: udp examples incorrectly run as part of testing
body: Some tests were failing because the UDP example was executed.

title: feat: add support for UDP sockets
body:
I wanted to work with UDP sockets and looked into the implementation in Rust's standard library. The API provided is different to TCP streams / listeners, in that there is no persistent connection when using UDP sockets. As such, special functions are required to work with them.

I have added four functions:
- `&udpb` binds a socket to an address
- `&udpr` receives a datagram in bytes on a socket
- `&udps` sends a datagram to an address on a socket
- `&udpsml` changes the maximum message length of a socket

The message length is required for receiving messages. It is used to initialize the buffer to which the datagram is written.
I decided to keep this state internally, as the value is unlikely to be changed often. This way, users don't have to provide the length every time a message is received.

I have tested the functions by sending datagrams to myself using multiple terminal sessions. I have also tested a simple pooled ping pong server, which worked.

title: fix crash when unparsing large unary numbers
Implement `parse` subscripts
body:
- implement base subscripts
- add tests for parse subscripts

title: Rehaul FFI
body:
- redo pointer reading
- setting mostly works, minor bugs
- get arrays to work
- repr structs
- get return types working properly

title: fix: use stderr for diagnostic data
fix: fork and fix in planet notation shorthand
body:
For some reason, planet notation only worked with strings of following forms:
- `fp`
- `f[gd]+[ip]`
- `[gd]{2,}`
- `d+f`

While the following did not work:
- `fi`
- `f[gd]+`
- `f[gd]*f`
- `[gd]*g[gd]*f`

Although it's a bit harder to describe using just regex — for instance, `ggdf` would parse, but as two juxtaposed shorthands, like `gg df`.

With this change, planet notation is treated as described by [Planet aliases](https://www.uiua.org/docs/idioms#planet-aliases): that is, `f?[gd]*[fip]?` containing at least two characters.

title: fix(nix): pass `--try-file` when running the site
body: Follow-up to #757. Needed to make all site features usable due to it being a SPA.

title: feat: complete handshake using rustls when calling &tcpa on a tls listener
body: Using TLS requires the participants to complete a handshake. This functionality is available in `rustls`, and it almost never makes sense to not complete the handshake. As Uiua wants to offer a higher level API, I think automatically conducting the handshake when accepting a connection makes a lot of sense. Implementing this on the user side would require using a library like OpenSSL w/ FFI and side-stepping `&tlsl` entirely. I tested this change using a website server.

title: fix returned handle when calling &tcpa on a tls listener
body: I was working with TLS listeners and the program would sometimes crash when setting the read timeout. This was only after I closed a connection. I noticed the handle to the listener and connection were the same number, and found that the returned handle is the one from the listener, not the newly created stream handle. This was just due to a small scoping issue. I have tested the change alongside [this change](https://github.com/uiua-lang/uiua/compare/main...donstenzel:uiua:tls-handshake) in a website server and it works correctly now.

title: mark erroring example in audio docs
Fix several `it's` -> `its` in error messages and docs
Update changelog to reflect the Return of `kork`
Update changelog for `-e` -> `-x` change
body: Sorry, forgot to include this as part of #761

title: Make `experimental` flags consistent in `uiua eval` and `uiua repl`
body:
`uiua eval -e` -> `uiua eval -x` to match `uiua repl -x`
Also changed the description of `uiua repl`'s experimental flag' to match that of `uiua eval`

title: Make dip and on function packs start from zero
body: > This change makes most usecases of these function packs cleaner, as `A⊙(B|C)` changes to `⊙(A|B|C)` and likewise for `on ⟜`

title: feat(nix): site derivation
body: This change allows building the website with Nix. Also includes an app to build and run the site using `nix run .#site`.

title: Slightly rearrange changelog
body: This is super nitpicky but it was bothering me that the things that were deprecated/removed in favor of exponential were broken in the middle by the `&seek` entry.

title: thats just a bug waiting to happen
mention fills in group and partition docs
Fix bugs with under shape fill handling
body:
- Fixes crash when attempting to set a non-empty shape of an empty array without a fill value
- Fixes type matching for filled under shape

title: Several docs fixes
body: Scrolled up in the docs bugs Discord thread and found that several of them had not been fixed yet.

title: make removing # Experimental! easier
body:
- Add the shortcut ctrl+shift+E
- Make the 🧪 button remove experimental comment if it's there
- Make ctrl+E (and 🧪) more consistent

title: Update primitives.json to reflect `&seek` docs change
support &seek in pad
body: Use custom `StreamSeek` enum, because `std::io::SeekFrom` allows for more cases than we are using

title: Improve commenting keyboard shortcut in the pad
body:
This PR makes a number of fixes to the pad's keyboard shortcut for turning a selection of lines into a comment or multiline string.
- The endpoint positions of the selection are adjusted accordingly based on where comment tokens have been placed or removed and where the selection endpoints were originally. This means that the selection will no longer move around wildly when (un)commenting large amounts of code.
- If the selection being commented spans multiple lines, but the final line it reaches is reached only by the selection including the newline character that comes before the actual content of that line, that final line will be excluded. This means no more awkward commenting of an extra line after the set of lines that you meant to comment.
- When commenting code that spans multiple different indentation levels, comment tokens are all aligned to the highest indentation level. This means that if you comment a large chunk of code with multiple indentation levels in it, it won't end up with strangely placed comment tokens that lead the formatter to remove all indentation from the commented code. This also means that indentation won't be lost when turning an entire block into a multiline string.
- Blank lines are ignored completely when commenting, since there isn't really a reason to have lines that are just `# ` in your commented code. This does not apply to multiline strings, since it would break what was likely intended to be a single string into multiple if it did.

Build the site locally and try selecting and commenting different parts of this code. Compare with the existing pad and you'll see that this PR makes it much more well-behaved.
```
[
  [1 2]

  [3 4]
]

```
For instance, if you select all with ctrl/cmd A and then use the comment shortcut, the current behavior will do this:
```
# [
  # [1 2]
# 
  # [3 4]
# ]
# 

```
This pull request makes it do this:
```
# [
#   [1 2]

#   [3 4]
# ]

```
If you were to select only the middle three lines and comment, the current behavior is
```
[
  # [1 2]
# 
  # [3 4]
]

```
Now it will be
```
[
  # [1 2]

  # [3 4]
]

```
This is in addition to the fact that again, the selection will no longer move around wildly because of the text length changing when you comment/uncomment. Currently, if you hit the shortcut twice in a row, it is rather likely that the selection after commenting will span fewer lines than before commenting, so you'll end up not uncommenting all the lines that were previously commented. This buggy behavior is fixed by this PR.

title: Tweak ordering of changelog entries
body: The bullet point for adding `exponential` should come before both bullets for removing things in favor of it.

title: Add `unby` as a documented compound
body: For when you hover over `°⊸` in the pad

title: fix private macros beeing 'private unused' in the LSP when they are used
Fix asymmetry between ∞ and ¯∞ in mean when outputting large arrays
Add assert for sizeof(usize)>=sizeof(u32)
body: Many parts of the code rely on this hidden assumption, this makes it concrete at compile time

title: fix edgecase where joining two u32 max length arrays overflows
body:
before this pr, when running `do(join.|1) [1]`:
```
The application panicked (crashed).
Message:  range start index 4294967295 out of range for slice of length 0
Location: src/algorithm/dyadic/combine.rs:399
```

[bug report on the Discord](https://discord.com/channels/1156339038748413952/1385117433681022986)

title: Fix crash when under shape is used with an empty shape

title: make dims_to_flat and i_dims_to_flat accept an iter
Tiling `under shape`
body: At the moment, this PR is not ready to merge, as I am not sure about the way I have gone about implementing this functionality, still need to handle negatives and infinities, and am also not sure that all edge cases are covered yet. I am creating this PR as a draft so that feedback can be provided. I've left `TODO`s in that I will have to go back for.

title: Orient duplicate axis bug
body: The existing implementation was only checking for adjacent duplicate axes, and caused orient to malfunction if given nonadjacent duplicate axes. This fixes this and adds a test for it.

title: Update tests to use round subscripts
body: A couple of them were even using `⍜×⁅1000000000000`…

title: fix multiple crashes with or and undiv on infinite values
Fix bug with under fork
body: My original implementation of under fork would break if under's second function touched anything beneath the outputs of the first function on the stack. This fixes that issue.

title: Under fork monadic
body: Modify and set multiple properties at once with `⍜⊃` and `°⊸⊃`!

title: remove .envrc
body:
The .envrc is needed for setting up local environment automatically. Naturally, different developers have different needs. With .envrc being tracked, not only a certain configuration is forced, it is also not possible to override this configuration. Ideally, .envrc should be placed in the user's global gitignore, if they wish to use direnv.

See direnv/direnv#556 for more motivation and complaints.

title: assert value size less or equal to 64 bytes
add new optimization for sign len path
body: Hey, the person from discord here. I decided to try implementing an optimization for sign len path myself. Hope it's usable :)

title: Fix reversed aromantic flag
body: I'm curious how this happened in the first place.

title: add alias "dnod" for drop negate on drop
body: Since `adnoad` was added for padding on both sides, it makes sense that the opposite operation of dropping on both sides should have an alias too.

title: fix saturation formula for domain coloring
body: now it doesn't overflow the channel, which should stay in [0,1]

title: add see also links between minimum and maximum
body:
Hi

This small addition to the doc eases cross-references between `minimum` and `maximum` (like it's already the case between `first` and `last` for example…)

Thanks for this great project!

title: fix negative hues not working as expected
body: casting to usize messed up the sign, casting to isize + using modulus instead of remainder fixed it

title: update libffi to version 4, fix compilation on macOS
Add subscripts for `length` and `shape`
body:
Subscripted `length` gets the length of the Nth axis.
Subscripted `shape` gets the shape from the first N axes.

Side note, why is the internal name for `⧻` `Len` and not `Length`?

title: Rewrite :fix: section of the Advanced section
body: Continues https://github.com/uiua-lang/uiua/pull/688

title: fix root
body: Roots are well defined for negatives, this seems to be a bug

title: add tuples change to the changelog
